p: News from you has been so very scarce lately - why? I hope you are well, at least.

One day flies by after another; time surely passes too quickly. I wish we could see you once in awhile. Albert's making the trip is impossible because he could get no time off - it has nothing to do with expenses.
I had a wonderful time with Millie the other day. She took me to lunch at the Castilla.
Last Sunday Albert adn I swam all day and got a fine sunburn. Albert suffered quite a bit, although he was not blistered. I hope we go again soon before we lose our tan.
This evening we are going to visit
The Roger Sibson's. Roger is a young man in Alberts department. They are both very nice, and I'm glad we're going.
I have been practising every day - there is no news.
Did you by any chance find that white card showing I was registered with the U.S. Note Dept.? You will remember I had it when in Branson, now I need to return it and cannot find it.
Albert is busy on our Book. Sig is practising at Amama's. Maxie is cleaning in the kitchen.
By the way, we are finally getting our new wallpaper!
Please write soon - I missing hearing from you.
stamp: UNITED STATES POSTAGE THOMAS JERRERSON 1801-1809 3 CENTS 3
